THE MAYORALTY
(By Special Telegraph.)
Your vote and influence is respectfully
extended for
JOHN F. BETTS
As Mayor at the coming election.
Election takes place on Monday,
January 3, 1887.

CARD
To the Voters of the Town of
Prince Albert.
Gentlemen:
Being unable at this season to make a
special call upon each elector, I would ask
all electors who can place sufficient confi-
dence in me to use my influence and
votes in my behalf at the polls Monday
next.
Yours respectfully,
T. J. AGNEW.

STRAYED!

THE TELEGRAPHIC CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

WEDNESDAY, Dec. 29.
The Ontario elections took place today
and resulted in the return of the
following candidates: Mowat's majority
being even greater than the last par-
liament.
Ministerialists—Algoma East, Lyon;
Algoma West, Conser; Caribou North,
White; Beaver, Hargrave; Beaver South,
O'Connor; Beaver Centre, Dock-
beverley; Beaver, Danby; Chamber-
lain, Smith; Caribou North, Macdon-
ald; Caribou South, Pennefather; Essex
North, Pennefather; Essex South, Ba-
tton; Essex East, Murray; Grey County,
Burton; Hastings East, Macdonald; East
Glengarry, Haywood; Ross, Hardinge;
Bates; Kent East, Ferguson; Kent West,
East Grand River, Lambton West;
Middlesex West, Rose; Middlesex East,
Norton; Norfolk East, Mosch; Norfolk

Oxford West, McKay; Parry Sound,
Armstrong; Peel, Chisholm; Peterboro-
west, Brown; Prince Edward, Smythe;
Renfrew East, Murray; Renfrew South,
Macdonald; Renfrew West, Bellfield;
Renfrew North, Prince; Renfrew Centre,
Denny; Simcoe, Mack; Waterloo

Wellington South, Gauthier; Wentworth

Stewart; Durham East, Cona; Egerton
West, Ingram; Frontenac, Wightman;

Gravelle; Hastings East, Hartlage East;

Wood; Huron East, Hamilton; Huron West,

Lanark, Macdonald; Lennoxville; Lan-
ark North, Macdonald; Lennoxville;
Martinique, Martinique North, Smith;
Martinique South, Martinique East,
Wilkinson; Middlesex East, Wilkinson;
Middlesex West, Wilkinson; Northumberland
East, Wyler; Northumberland West,
Wyler; Toronto East, Clarke; Toronto West,
Clarke; Victoria East, Ferri; Victoria West,
Ferri.
Mr. MacKay and D.H. Macdonald
of Prince Albert, are in the city, and
will proceed home immediately.
The funeral of the late Governor Legge
will take place this afternoon at the Anglican
Church on Friday.

WEDNESDAY, Dec. 30.
The religious delegates have arrived
in Regina with a number of interesting id-
eas in their hands.
An important meeting of the British
Cabinet was held yesterday. Salisbury
stated that the Cabinet had not yet
reached a conclusion, and intimated that it
would still remain and would not give an
answer until the Cabinet had been
consulted.
Final returns—Ministerialists—East
Petrolia, Richmond; Fairy Sound, Arm-
strong; Canterbury, Rockey; North
Bruce, Biggar; West Scott, Clancy;
Hastings North, Wood; Hastings West,
Wood; Huron East, Hamilton; Huron West,
Clancy; Kingston, Maclean; Lanark South,
Lanark, Macdonald; Lennoxville; Lan-
ark North, Macdonald; Lennoxville;
Martinique, Martinique North, Smith;
Martinique South, Martinique East,
Wilkinson; Martinique West, Wilkinson;
Middlesex East, Wilkinson; Middlesex West,
Wilkinson; Northumberland East, Wyler;
Northumberland West, Wyler; Toronto East,
Clarke; Toronto West, Clarke; Victoria East,
Ferri; Victoria West, Ferri.

An entertainment was given by the
young ladies of Mrs. Carter at the close
of the examination last night.
About 400 people, ladies, gentlemen and
boys attended the last term.
Interesting little boys attracted the
eyes of many ladies and children who came
in public schools are taught, as
well as French and other branches.
A musical concert was given by the
students for the benefit of Monday night.
Saturday 1st the Vagrant Act 1890,
which is in operation in the North-West
Territories, was discussed following the
meeting. Only two of the old Council were
nominated as they did not wish for
another term.
J.F. Clark, Mr. Clark's Crossing, was
elected for the Mayoralty, and Ald. Burrows, Dr.
James T. Agnew, A.B. Clark, J. L.
Johnson, and Mr. Johnson, for Aldermen.
The election will be held next week.

Happy New Year.
J.F. Clark, Mr. Clark's Crossing.
In town last week.

The grand opening of the Saskatchewan
Club Christmas Eve.

Five per cent discount on Xmas and
New Year's cards at Cain's bookstore.
Pocket and other shades for 188—
beautiful designs at reasonable prices.
A concert will take place on the Sas-
katchewan Park next week from nine
to eleven o'clock.

Service was held in St. Alban's Church
on Christmas Day, Rev. Mr. Wright of
leading.

The declaration of the result of the
Municipal election will be made at
12 o'clock on Tuesday.

Wagner's holiday sale of dry goods
will last ten days. Goods also
marked down.

The annual Rifle Association meeting
will take place on the 13th of January.

The T.A. Band played at the Anglican
Church on Wednesday, but the weather
being very cold very few were present.

The roll of the Liberal Club was
read at the meeting of the
office of the secretary, Mr. T. N. Campbell.

Mr. Burrows has a large stock of
clothing, crackers, candles, sugar, beef
meat and pork on hand. No less dis-
plays have been seen in years past.

Funeral services were held at Mr. Joseph
Fuson's on the 29th of December, when
it was announced that a number of our citizens
were laid to rest. A very enjoyable evening
was spent.

The first regiment of Government
scouts was made by Mr. Lewis, of
Regina, who has been engaged for
two months in the business, and in
charge of which are 30 members of
the force.

About 200 persons were on the roll of the
school conducted by the
Rev. Mothers of St. Ann's during the
past year, and the average attendance
was 100.

Christmas tree will be given, in the
Presbyterian church, to anyone after-
noon who has children who are
not attending the singing practice for
the service.

The singing practice for the
service.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW,
PUBLISHED BY
J. D. MAVEETY
PRINCE ALBERT N.W.T.,
FRIDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1866.

THE OLD YEAR.
The old year goes away like a shadow, and there are many hopes will be realized with the east. It enters into the abyss of the dead, taking with it all our dreams and hopes for a considerable time. The world has come into its own, and we, as people, have peace with itself and Wigner. And yet, notwithstanding these prophecies, people's attention. Some great men, however, in all ages have been looked upon as fools who will live in history for all time to come. But with the years we come and with them there are new hopes and dreams. All we have to do is to believe what we see here, a blessing. Time turns its wheel without the notice and the pride of the people around us.

MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS.
If we are not fortunate enough to secure a good Council for the ensuing year the people of Prince Albert will be to blame, as they have always been accustomed to select a sufficient good majority out of which to select five good men. We will see how the election will turn out in their favor, and that the municipal interests will be allowed to be in the hands of those who are in the know.

Two weeks ago the ballot, so that there was no possibility of it being altered by the electors. We called attention some weeks ago to the fact that by the amendment made to the Municipal Act (1864) has been left to Municipal Councils to decide whether or not they have paid their taxes shall affect them at Municipal elections, but we do not know whether they go in force immediately. At all events, it will be necessary to take action now, and those who have not paid their taxes ought to appeal in the matter of the ballot now coming up. There are, we understand, about 125 names on the voters' list, of which about 60 names are registered property. The poll will open at nine o'clock Monday next, in the Council Chamber, and close at 3 p.m.

HALFBREEDS SLANDERED.
Hon. William Laurier, the leader of the French Liberals, and a man who boasted that he would have done had he been on the banks of the Saskatchewan when the rebellion broke out, made a speech yesterday afternoon before the Delegates of the various provinces, where he attacked the halfbreeds and the causes that led to it. After referring to the history of the halfbreeds, he said that they showed unwavering loyalty to British institutions since they became British subjects, he had been asked why he refused to show the same courage as if he had his rifle on his shoulder, and rolled from off his silvery tongue a ringing, contemptuous slander against the Métis.

"You may say that the wretched halfbreeds are not fit to be compared to the heroes of British history. If you say so, so do I."

We have reason to print some hard things about the halfbreeds, but it is known to be false, that the Roman Catholic party has been the most slander against them than belongs to Mr. Laurier. We do not know how far they would go to defend the halfbreeds would compare with the "heroes of British history," but we know that, but for the Roman Catholic party, the halfbreeds like Laurier would have not have broken their record as a possible, Christian and patriotic people. They are doing just what ought to be done, and they are doing it.

ONTARIO ELECTIONS.
The interesting question involved in Mr. Mowat being sustained by an increased majority. To those who are convinced that Mr. Mowat is the Premier of Ontario, and the somewhat similar course pursued by the Mold of Prince Albert, may be justified. Since Mr. Mowat obtained power he has endeavored to strengthen his hands by every possible means. He has been very persistent in his efforts to get the Imperial government to recognize the Municipal Councils that would give him power over the liberties of the people. He has been persistent in his efforts to point out the Inspectorate, and by that means has been able to control over the Imperial elections. He has been doing everything and anything to make Oliver Mowat and his colleagues life rulers of this province. In view of the evidence of change of policy on the part of the Mold of Prince Albert, and the support of local opinion to a radical Federationist, we feel justified in predicting that the Liberal candidates into office will be very few indeed. But as it is impossible for Mr. Mowat to complete as possible, the Mold took to doing the Separate School system on Ontario. The Separate School system on Ontario is a device to drive the Roman Catholics and driving the Roman Catholics away from the schools, as it has been the case in the past.

To add to his prestige came the sudden change of policy on the part of the Mold. He became a supporter of local opinion to a radical Federationist, which will enable him to drive those who were opposed to prohibition and the licensed saloonists into the ranks of the anti-prohibitionists whom they loved the latter more, but because they loved prohibition less. But as it is impossible for Mr. Mowat to complete as possible, the Mold took to doing the Separate School system on Ontario. The Separate School system on Ontario is a device to drive the Roman Catholics away from the schools, as it has been the case in the past.

COMMUNICATIONS.
HE RISES TO EXPLAIN.
For the Editor of the Times.
Sir,—Mr. J. F. Coley, of Clarke's Crossing, who passed through here a few days ago on his way to Prince Albert, spoke to me a half hour ago, and has been circulating falsehoods in relation to me that are more nearly than the pack of cards that he used to throw at me. These statements of Mr. Clarke are made with a view to injure me with the electors of the district in gratitude for his petty political services. I do justice to and find for the information of the public who do not know the motives that prompted the remarks, I state that Mr. Clarke has been here and at other places he has said that I can only take one vote in the election. I believe that it is not in my best interest to say anything less than a dozen votes, as it is easy for me to get Mr. Mowat's version. I submit a few extracts from the speeches made by Mr. Clarke at the meeting the evening before, the 20th inst., and also for your publication, if it does not trespass too greatly upon your limited and valuable space.

Yours respectfully,

N. B. Stewart, Dec. 29, 1866.

A meeting of the electors of this district was held in the schoolhouse this morning, for the purpose of considering the question of nominating a candidate to the House of Commons. After some discussion, Mr. Peter Stobart, President, as proposed by Mr. Peter Latham; Mr. Molloy was nominated by Mr. Tracey, seconded by Mr. Stewart, and Mr. Molloy, taken by ballot Mr. Molloy was declared by the chairman to be the choice of the meeting. Mr. Tracey then moved that this nomination be made unanimous, which was carried. The following gentlemen were nominated for the position: Messrs. Tracey, McMillan, Molloy, Latham, and Stewart.

(Signed) J. N. Guthrie, Chairman.

F. W. Kain, Sec.

I did not attend that meeting to secure a nomination as stated publicly there, but to urge the electors to use their votes for one man when the time came, and in this I was generously aided by Mr. Tracey, and the movement of my nomination unanimous was most cheerfully received and enthusiastically carried.

Yours respectfully,

B. J. Molloy.

Lt. Governor Dewdney has gone to Ottawa and other eastern points.

CHRISTMAS EVE AT ST. CATHERINE'S.

A very enjoyable evening was held at St. Catherine's on Christmas Eve, the occasion being an entertainment provided by Miss McGregor for her pupils in the parish. The children were all present—some in body and behaved with great decorum—the very youngest being, like Tiny Tim, "as poor as a gold." There was a large attendance of parents, who filled the church being quite filled, even after temporary seats had been placed from time to time. One Carol greeted us, and the utmost good humor prevailed throughout.

Added by numerous friends to the district and in Prince Albert, Miss McGregor had been successful in providing a Christmas tree loaded with gifts from abroad to be seen every day in the Northwest. Mr. Inskster acted as Father Christmas and, with his wife, Mrs. Inskster, soon stripped the tree of its load, and the delighted eyes of the youngsters as they opened their presents were a joy to study. The articles for distribution have been selected with care and judgment and are sure to give much satisfaction, receiving some notice at once useful and ornamental along with a Christmas card and a gift. The children were most enthusiastic about the gifts, and the parents, too, were pleased with the selection made.

EAST END SCHOOL ANNUAL EXAMINATION.

The Christmas examination of the pupils attending the school was held in the schoolroom on Friday, December 21st. The examiners were Messrs. McLeod, Robert Robertson, and Mr. McKenzie. The teacher conducted the examination in a most satisfactory manner, and received great praise from all present for the marked improvement shown by the pupils. The answers to all subjects had been gone through by the principal, and were distributed by the teacher. Each child was given a certificate acknowledging the satisfactory manner in which he had answered the questions.

HIGH SCHOOL EXAMINATION.

The Christmas examination of the Prince Albert High School took place on Friday, December 21st, in the presence of quite a number of parents of the pupils and others interested in the welfare of the school. The following classes were examined in Reading, Arithmetic, Algebra, Latin, French, English Grammar, Geography, Voice Music, and Drawing; the correctness of the answers given, in most instances, bearing witness to the thoroughness of the instruction received. After the conclusion of the examination by Bain, who occupied the chair, the students were dismissed on the understanding that those who had failed in any subject would be allowed to remain by the influence of the parents. After Christmas cards were distributed, the school was closed until January 1st. It was announced that the class would reopen on Monday, December 31st, 1886.

ST. LAURENT.

(Special to The Prince.)

Mr. R. J. Molloy addressed a meeting of the electors here this afternoon. Representing the present town of St. Louis, Mr. Molloy spoke of the importance of the election to be held next month. After hearing Mr. Molloy, who strongly urged unity of action on the part of the electors, Mr. Molloy stated that he would resolve that the vote in this district should be united, and to this end would meet with the members of the district between the 15th and the 10th of January, to which Mr. Molloy has been invited. He was also invited to attend a mass meeting at Buffalo this evening.

THE BAKING POWDER.

The competitive examination for the silver medals was presided over by Mr. John Stewart and John Macdonald, one to be awarded to the competitor making the highest percentage and the other to the boy making the highest percentage, took place on Saturday, December 21st. The Inspector, Rev. Canon Pitt, examined each class in the various branches handled.

The following list of competitors was presented to the successful applicants at the opening of school. Agnes Thompson, of the Second Class, and Willie McLeod, of the Second Class, were the only competitors. Following is a list of those who made over 50 per cent., each class being represented by two pupils:

Senior Div., 1st Part.—James McLeod, Willie McKenzie, Robert Robertson, and Mr. McKenzie.

Junior Div., 2nd Part.—James McLeod, Alice Stewart, George Macintosh, Sarah Ann Sherr, Jessie Macintosh.

Junior Div., 3rd Part.—Edward Gordon, William Carter and William Campbell, equal; Virginia McKay, Douglas Murray.

Senior Class.—William MacBeth, Harry Robertson; Joseph Macdonald and Frank Robertson, equal; Arthur Jardine.

Third Class.—Margaret Murray and Edith Gordon, equal; Arthur Way, John McLeod, Anne Cameron, Ada Murray, James Murray, and William Murray.

Fourth Class.—Agnes Thompson; Geo. Ballantine and Bella Dilworth, equal; Win. Murray, Anna McGaffer.

A scratch curling match took place on Christmas afternoon between the teams, consisting of members of the Saskatoon curling club, Messrs. Sanderson and Nelson against Mr. Murray and Thomas Murray. Though the weather was exceedingly cold, the players seemed to enjoy themselves. Mr. Sanderson's team were victorious.
